chapter.htmlHeader: Desmopressin

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the contraindications and cautions for desmopressin?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Do not prescribe desmopressin:
    • To people with:
      • Cardiac insufficiency.
      • Conditions treated with diuretics.
      • Psychogenic polydipsia or alcohol abuse.
      • Known history of hyponatraemia. 
      • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.
    • For primary nocturnal enuresis and nocturia associated with multiple sclerosis in people aged over 65 years.
  • Prescribe desmopressin with caution in:
    • People with:
      • Asthma.
      • Cardiovascular disease (not indicated for nocturnal enuresis or nocturia).
      • Conditions which might be aggravated by water retention.
      • Cystic fibrosis.
      • Hypertension (not indicated for nocturnal enuresis or nocturia).
      • Epilepsy.
      • Migraine.
      • Nocturia or nocturnal enuresis — limit fluid intake to minimum from 1 hour before dose until 8 hours afterwards.
      • Renal impairment — antidiuretic effect may be reduced.
    • Elderly people (age 65 years and older) — they are at increased risk of hyponatraemia and renal impairment. The manufacturer advises that in elderly men [ABPI, 2016c]:
      • Daily doses above 50 micrograms should not be used.
      • Serum sodium levels should be monitored before initiating treatment, in the first week of treatment (4–8 days after initiation) and again at one month after treatment initiation. Desmopressin treatment should be discontinued if the serum sodium level falls below the lower limit of normal range (135 mmol/L).
      • Treatment should be reviewed if there is no therapeutic benefit after 3 months.

[ABPI, 2016c; BNF 76, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I start and titrate desmopressin?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The recommended dose of oral lyophilisate desmopressin (Noqdirna®) for idiopathic nocturnal polyuria in men is 50 micrograms daily taken one hour before bedtime, administered sublingually without water.
  • Assess the man's response after a trial of 1–2 weeks' treatment.
    • A dose increase with this product is not recommended in elderly people (age 65 years and older).
    • If higher doses are considered for people aged younger than 65 years in case of an insufficient response to Noqdirna®, other desmopressin oral lyophilisate products should be used.

[ABPI, 2016c]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of desmopressin?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Fluid retention and hyponatraemia can occur, leading to headache, nausea and vomiting, weight gain, and convulsions (in serious cases).
    • To reduce the risk of hyponatraemic convulsions, advise the person to:
      • Drink only enough to satisfy their thirst, avoid drinking fluids in the last 1–2 hours before bed, and avoid drinking fluids for 8 hours after taking desmopressin.
      • Stop taking desmopressin during periods of diarrhoea or vomiting (until fluid balance is normal).
      • Avoid using over-the-counter ibuprofen or aspirin as they may worsen water retention and increase the risk of hyponatraemia.
    • In the event of signs or symptoms of water retention and/or hyponatremia (headache, nausea/vomiting, weight gain, and, in severe cases, convulsions), treatment should be interrupted and reassessed. If restarting treatment, strict fluid restriction should be enforced and serum sodium levels monitored.
    • The risk of hyponatremia is higher in people aged 65 years of age or older.
  • Other possible adverse effects of desmopressin include:
    • Frequency not known — abdominal pain, allergic dermatitis, and emotional disorder, epistaxis, and nasal congestion.

[ABPI, 2016c; BNF 76, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the key drug interactions of desmopressin?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Drug interactions of desmopressin include [ABPI, 2016c; BNF 76, 2018]:
    • Drugs known to induce syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone hypersecretion (SIADH) — concurrent use of desmopressin and drugs known to induce SIADH (such as tricyclic antidepressants, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, chlorpromazine, diuretics, and carbamazepine) may cause an increased risk of water retention and/or hyponatremia.
      • If concurrent use cannot be avoided, monitor closely for symptoms of water retention and/or hyponatremia (headache, nausea/vomiting, weight gain, and, in severe cases, convulsions).
    • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and aspirin — may potentiate the antidiuretic effect of desmopressin and may induce water retention and/or hyponatremia.
      • If concurrent use cannot be avoided, monitor closely for symptoms of water retention and/or hyponatremia.
    • Loperamide — concurrent use with desmopressin may result in a 3-fold increase of desmopressin plasma concentrations following oral administration, which may lead to an increased risk of water retention and/or hyponatremia.
      • If concurrent use cannot be avoided, monitor closely for symptoms of water retention and/or hyponatraemia.
    • Lithium — may diminish the antidiuretic effect of desmopressin.
      • Special caution should be exercised in people taking lithium in case of masking of early-stage lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by administration of desmopressin for a nocturia indication.
      • Desmopressin is not recommended in people suspected of having lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
  • For a complete list of possible drug interactions of desmopressin, see the electronic Medicines Compendium (eMC) or the British National Formulary (BNF).

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I monitor a person taking desmopressin?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Elderly people are at increased risk of developing hyponatraemia with desmopressin treatment and may also have impaired renal function.
    • The manufacturer advises that in elderly men (age 65 years and older):
      • Daily doses above 50 micrograms should not be used.
      • Serum sodium levels should be monitored before initiating treatment, in the first week of treatment (4–8 days after initiation) and again at one month after treatment initiation. Desmopressin treatment should be discontinued if the serum sodium level falls below the lower limit of normal range (135 mmol/L).
      • Treatment should be reviewed if there is no therapeutic benefit after 3 months.
  • Periodic blood pressure and body weight checks are recommended to monitor fluid overload.
  • In the event of signs or symptoms of water retention and/or hyponatremia (headache, nausea/vomiting, weight gain, and, in severe cases, convulsions), treatment should be interrupted and reassessed.
    • If restarting treatment strict fluid restriction should be enforced and serum sodium levels monitored.

[ABPI, 2016c; BNF 76, 2018]
